raw_text:
Labour MP praises Tory campaign
 
 The Conservatives have been "a lot smarter" in the way they have conducted the general election campaign, a Labour backbencher has said.
 
 Derek Wyatt said having a five month campaign "turned off voters" and suggested people were already "rather bored of the thing". He wants a greater campaigning role for Chancellor Gordon Brown. Labour said the economy was at the heart of the campaign and Mr Brown therefore had a prominent role. But Mr Wyatt argued: "By some way, he is currently the figure in all of the polls that people trust and see that has delivered over eight years an economy unmatched anywhere in the world. "So, it would be a tad foolish of the Labour Party if we did not use him as we have done over the past three elections."
 
 Labour's election chief Alan Milburn denied there was an attempt to sideline Mr Brown after facing criticism for letting the Tories set the agenda. However, Mr Wyatt predicted the campaign would get under way properly once the chancellor delivered his budget. The MP for Sittingbourne and Sheppey said Prime Minister Tony Blair had been "trying very hard" to improve his own standing with the electorate through a "sort of campaign of trust". But Mr Blair had been "hurt" by the Iraq controversy, he added. A Labour party spokesman played down differences with Mr Wyatt and said Mr Brown already had a prominent campaign role. "This election is a choice between Labour taking Britain forward and the Conservatives taking us back."
llama3.2:1b: Labour MP Derek Wyatt praises Tory campaign, saying they are "a lot smarter" in their approach to the general election.
He argues that Chancellor Gordon Brown should have a greater campaigning role.
Labour has denied any attempt to sideline Brown, but Wyatt predicts the campaign will start properly once he delivers his budget.
llama3.2:3b: Labour MP Derek Wyatt praises Conservative campaign tactics, suggesting they were smarter and more effective.
He argues that Chancellor Gordon Brown should have a greater campaigning role, as he is currently the most trusted figure in polls.
The Labour Party denies an attempt to sideline Mr. Brown, but predicts he will play a key role once he delivers his budget, which marks the start of their campaign.

Wyatt also mentions Blair's efforts to improve his standing through public trust campaigns but notes it was "hurt" by the Iraq controversy.

The Labour Party said the economy was at the heart of the campaign and Mr Brown therefore had a prominent role.
Mr Wyatt argued: "By some way, he is currently the figure in all of the polls that people trust and see that has delivered over eight years an economy unmatched anywhere in the world."

Labour's election chief Alan Milburn denied there was an attempt to sideline Mr Brown after facing criticism for letting the Tories set the agenda.
However, Mr Wyatt predicted the campaign would get under way properly once the chancellor delivered his budget.
The MP for Sittingbourne and Sheppey said Tony Blair had been "trying very hard" to improve his own standing with the electorate through a "sort of campaign of trust".
However, Mr Blair had been "hurt" by the Iraq controversy, he added.
A Labour party speaker played down differences with Mr Wyatt and suggested Mr Brown already had a prominent campaign role.
The message of this election is clear: Labour taking Britain forward rather than the Conservatives.

Derek Wyatt argues the five-month campaign has turned voters off and calls for a stronger role for Chancellor Gordon Brown.
He claims Brown, in his past campaigns, delivered an unmatched economy through spending.
The text also notes that while Blair tried to improve voter support, he faced criticism over Iraq.
Overall, it highlights the tension between Labour's emphasis on economic growth and focus on voters versus Blair's political struggles.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Conservatives' general election campaign has been characterized as a "sort of campaign of trust" by Labour backbencher Derek Wyatt, who believes that the economy being the primary issue drove a lackluster performance in terms of engaging voters.
However, Mr. Wyatt did praise Prime Minister Gordon Brown for his role in the campaign and suggested that the economy was at the heart of their efforts to retain his trust.
The Labour Party is expected to have a prominent campaigning role for the next three elections once Chancellor Blair's budget sets the agenda.
Mr. Wyatt also warned against letting Prime Minister Tony Blair slip out of the spotlight, saying he had been "trying very hard" to improve his own standing with voters through a new campaign.
